I used to work as a welder.  One hot summer day we opened the bay doors to let the breeze come through.  My welding station was about 15 feet away from the door. A simple thought destin, as well as anyone else who is curious. This is a basic, broad and general thought with not much testing but, why are you attracted to light? Maybe not so much the bulb itself for you and i, but more so the area of light being lit up. You can see easier. Now, owels and bats may not be atttacted to light in the same way, since they can operate and function with night vision. And plants may not "see" necessarily, yet theres something they still recieve from it as a source and or tool. Seeing is important, whether it be visually or perspectively. How can we do anything and accomplish anything without the ability to see (even within the realm of understanding). Different animals have different methods for being able to see, to accomplish the very same task than any other animal does that may use a polar opposite method for seeing. Same tasks, different methods of seeing, yet all are seeing to accomplish their task one after the other. Specific kinds of animals/insects may not have a "mysteriously special purpose or reason" for being attracted to light anymore than you and i do. They just may not know how to live and do much without a light source available if they dont have night vision as an option.

I have a different hypothesis on this subject. My dad noticed that the moths seemed to pass out after being around the light for too long. They would pile up on the ground, or table under the light, but they would be gone by morning. I watched and never saw anything eating the moths and never found moth parts that would suggest they had been eaten. It appeared to me that the moths were passing out and falling, then eventually regaining consciousness and flying away. Given their erratic and excited behavior, it seemed to me that they were being excited by the artificial light to the point that many of them would pass out. The stimulus didn't seem to continue after the moth passed out, because they would be gone in the morning, even if the light was left on all night. It reminded me of how humans can become excited during certain "activities" in a way that will sometimes culminate in a dramatic loss of strength, coordination and even spasming is completely unrelated parts of the body. Some people have even been known to feint. While I don't suggest that there is evidence to support any similarities in the type of stimulation, I believe that there may be some similar principles at play. I believe that the moth is excited by many kinds of artificial light in a way that humans may not be able to relate to directly. I believe that the moth is attracted to this type of stimulation and can be frenzied to a point of either exhaustion, or passing out from over stimulation. I would love for an entomologist to study this concept further and see if this might possibly be what is happening. It would also explain the unpredictable flight paths that are sometimes eratic and sometimes straight into the light source (frenzy, instead of a calculated misunderstanding of its surroundings. Do you still have any interest in moths and their relationship with these lights? I would very much like to see some study on this hypothesis.

This is another fantastic and very interesting video.
Though I do take issue with Your statement that the question regarding the root cause and function of "why photo-tactic insects fly towards light sources" is a "simple thing to know".
I would argue that the motivations and underlying processes that control the behaviour of living creatures have the potential to be at least as complex and "hard" as any other scientific conundrum.
And it's simply a personal prejudice that tells You that this is a "simple problem", and this prejudice is based on the common fact that we humans at the pragmatic level don't search for the "complete scientific explanation" when trying to solve a problem or understand our environment. We "satisfice" i.e. we are satisfied with any solution that gives us a working method to either solve the problem at hand, or just gives us a conceptual understanding that enables us to interpret and to some extent predict our "surroundings" (simply put "helps us make sense of the world around us"). And I think Your mistake is very wide spread and common, most of us think this way about a great many things that are still "unknown at the principle level" i.e. we have pragmatic understanding and solutions, but we don't know the "root cause and functions" of all parts involved in the processes (of the solution)...But then again when do we actually know the "true initial root cause" of anything? When is it ok to stop asking "why"...
Still a very good video.

Hey Destin, there is one problem with the evidence you have given that disproves the first theory with the log travel path of the moths. You see, as you explain it, if the moth makes use of the moon as a tool of orientation, the space it travels through can be considered 2D. The moon is always up. In the case of a point source like a lamp, the space is 3D, meaning that the "moon" will sometimes be up, but can also be right, left, down relative to the moth. Therefore a moth would not take a 2D log path as you have shown, but that path would be twisted in 3D, as the photos show. In order to get better results, one should use a setup that puts the moon always above the moth (to simulate the 2D space).

I've always thought it's a born instinct to enable them to get out of the dark and tight spaces, like your clothes closet, where they spent their youth munching and then in chrysalid form.  So they have an instinct to seek light and move towards it in order to exit the closet, box, bark, tree hollow, or wherever they were holed up.  The light is then going to open out into the wide world where they may seek out a mate via those pheromones.  Artificial light interferes with this ancient instinct because other than phosphorescence, conflagrations and the sky, there was no other light source until humans invented candles. That is very recent in evolutionary terms.

It seems to me that we don't even know what kind of light (what specific wavelengths) bugs are attracted to. Back in the days of incandescents, they used to sell yellow light bulbs that supposedly didn't attract as many bugs (though I don't know whether that was ever scientifically proven.) Bug zappers have black light bulbs supposedly because they do better at attracting bugs, which again seems to be unproven and somewhat questionable. Some people below are assuming that bugs are actually searching out a source of heat, which would be infrared range, not light that's visible to us at all. Other people actually build fires to try to keep bugs away.

I really doubt the lunar theory. Bugs really can't fly in the direction of the moon like they can a nearby source of light. Even if they are using the moon as a navigation aid, bugs meander; they don't fly determinedly in a single direction, thus they would never get caught in a logarithmic spiral in an attempt to fly straight since straight flight is definitely not a bug behavior.

Bugs might be attracted to light because they are wanting to rendezvous with potential mates for reproduction, or they are wanting to hunt for food near the light. However, I don't see any mating or hunting behavior taking place near light sources so I think we can rule those ideas out.

Another possibility is that bugs are programmed to fly toward the light when seeking to escape from an enclosure. It makes sense that bugs should have an instinct that would allow them to find their way out of caves. It would also explain why bugs seem to be lost, disoriented, fascinated, and trapped by light sources and refuse to fly away. Rather, they repeatedly attempt to fly through transparent and translucent surfaces without ever understanding that a barrier is preventing their passage.

Just thinking out loud: I think that the logarithmic spiral model may assume too much. Can/do insects discern a slight change in the Moon's position as they fly? Why would they, for flights of a short duration? If they do not, they would regard it as a constant. If this is the case, the insect would always try to keep the Moon in a fixed position, for example, on its left. This would create more of a circular orbital path around a candle, which seems pretty consistent with real-life moths. Irregular paths should be expected, because artificial lights are hyper-stimulating the moth's natural ability to navigate: an ability that has been evolved over years and years of using a much smaller light to fly a straight line.

I don't know much about how retinas or visual cortexes work, but the explanation for why it happens on a film camera is fairly simple.

Imagine a fan with one blade painted bright red.  The red blade starts at 12 on the clock face and moves clockwise.  The film camera snaps a picture at 12.  Then blade spins almost all the way around an it snaps the next picture at 11 then 10, 9, 8 and so on.  It looks like it's spinning COUNTERclockwise on the film!

Forced movements, tropisms, and animal conduct by Jacques Loeb the physiologist.  He found the mechanism causing certain insects to fly toward the light called heliotropism. Basically light of different intensities causes different chemical changes in there retina which is connected to their motor apparatus. ie light hitting the right eye sets the left side motor apparatus in motion orientating the insect toward the light, when orientated the insect goes straight because both sides are even.
